head.title: A Tribute to the Memory of the Late Illustrious Gen. George Washington. Written for the 4th of July, 1802.11 Published in Massachusetts Spy, [Worcester, MA] (June 8, 1803), p. 4. Subsequently reprinted in Spectator [New York, NY] (July 6, 1803) with the additional subtitle “and delivered by the Author on his benefit night at the Charleston Theater.” In the 1801-1802 season Turnbull had two benefit nights: April 23 and May 14, 1802. On the first, he played the role of Sampson in his musical interlude, The Recruit and Mr. Harlow in Arthur Murphy's The Old Maid; he shared his second benefit nigh with his wife, who was cast in the role of Pantilina in the pantomime Care and Mirth, Mrs. Seymour and Jones. In the 1802-1803 season, Tunbull's benefit night was May 6, 1803 at which he played the role of Bonamo in Thomas Holcrofts's meladrama, A Tale of Mystery. See Richard Sodders, The Theatre Management of Alexandre Placide in Charleston, 1794-1812, vol. 2, unpub. Ph.D. diss. (Louisiana State University, 1983), pp. 502-503, 506, 530.

l.emph: Take him for all in all,
We shall not look upon his like again.

lg.l: When Liberty, bright progeny of Heav’n,33 “She [Freedom], the bright Progeny of Heaven, descends”: Phillis Wheatley, Liberty and Peace, line 5 (Boston: Warden and Russell, 1784).
Was from her ancient pristine glory driven,
And forc’d to quit her first belov’d abodes,
The feats of Heroes and of Demigods,
From orient climes she westward bent her way.
To where the ocean drowns Sol’s parting ray;
“Here far from tyrants and their gorgeous tow’rs,”
This clime, Columbia44 Poetic name, in use since the 1730s, for the original Thirteen Colonies of the United States. cry’d, “bright nymph, is yours."
“Here shalt thou, Goddess, ever more reside,
My sons your guards, and Washington their guide."
Return’d with glory from the bloody plain,
Sweet peace came dancing in her jocund train,
Display’d her olive branch, and bade once more
The arts to flourish round the happy shore,
Bade commerce here her choice treasures bring;
Rejoice, Columbians; To Paeans55 Songs of praise or exultation. sing!
From crime to crime the human mind is led,
One victim bleeds, because another bled;
The soldier who once shrank from blood and arms,
His only music now is war’s a’arms;
And, like the Macedonian youth of yore,
Mourns that his conquest can extend no more;
Not such, Columbians, your’s the thirst for blood;
Your hearts are gentle, as your cause was good;
Your foes subdu’d—soft pity, like the dove,
Descended from the radiant realms above,
Bade enmity be still, fell rancour cease,
And hail’d the reign of Industry and peace!
Now slaughter ceas’d where blood disgrac’d the side.
In p’acid streams the limped waters glide;
Where heaps of carnage strew’d the ensanguin’d plain.
Now toils in peace the inoffensive swain:
Where late the flames ascended to the skies
In rural pride the new-built hamlets rise,
And lofty towns, once levell’d to the ground,
Rear high their fyires, and wider spread around.
Behold your Chief returning from the field,
Resign the faulchion66 I.e., falchion: n. broad, slightly curved sword. and the bossy77 adj.adorned with ornamental protuberances, usually metal. shield;
With ever living laurels on his brow,

Your Cincinnatus88 Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus (519-430 BC), Roman aristocrat and statesman who was granted dictatorial powers in 458 BC; after defeating Rome’s enemies Cincinnatus returned to his farm, relinquishing his dictatorship and refusing military honors. Comparisons between Washington and Cincinnatus proliferated during the Revolutionary and early Republican period: see, e.g., Philip Freneau's poem “Occasioned by General Washington’s Arrival in Philadelphia…” in The Poems of Philip Freneau (Philadelphia: Francis Bailey, 1786), 356-359. reassumes the plough;
Grac’d with the civic robe, he once again
Hails his lov’d villa and domeste train;
And skill’d in peace, as well as war, to guide,
Behold him o’er your dearest rights preside;
And, foremost in the senatorial band,
Govern with equity his native land—
The pride, the glory of this wond’rous age,
The Father, Saint, the Soldier, and the Sage!
Read, O Columbians, o’er your hero’s bier,
Drop annually your grateful tribute here—
Lament your patriots mingled with the dust,
The wife, the brave, magnanimous and just—
Gone to that distant country, from whose bourn
The traveller shall never more return;
Yet, long as men shall read the historic page,
Their deeds shall live thro’ every distant age;
Each rising Hero shall their acts admire,
Glow as he reads, and catch heroic fire:
And as this season comes its annual round—
While patriot hearts with mighty joy rebound—
“Rejoice! Rejoice! and thus exulting say,
“’Tis Washington’s the tribute of the day,”
To him let then the glorious meed be given,
Renown on earth! Peace to his soul in Heav’n!
